Also the parallels between the Bible are clearly stated in the movie when they openly talk about the story of Cain and Abel. 

    For being a movie made in the 50's  the  overall effect that the movie left you with was the same that was felt after reading the book. The acting in the movie  was good, in that it portrayed the character that it was supposed to be and acted how the character was ideally supposed to be seen. 
Now, the acting was not the greatest compared to modern standards , and a few parts were funny even though they weren't supposed to. Overall the movie was a quality one that portrayed the correct themes and emotions as they should have been.

As an adaption of Steinbeck's novel, I find it to fall flat. The movie only contains parts of the later half of the book, and what it does show on the screen is watered down. The character development is missing, while important characters such as Lee are missing altogether. The original story's purpose was of free will, that Cal could overcome his evil blood, but to me the movie failed to convey this. As a movie in itself, it was decent. James Dean, Jo Van Fleet, and the scenery, not including the train ride sequences, brought it to life. I recommend it if you haven't read the book, or if it has been a while since reading, but don't watch right after you're finished reading it.

Being a movie from the 1950's, East of Eden was very well constructed and acted out by the characters but the main idea of the movie is more explained and said directly than it is portrayed and shown.
	The book, East of Eden uses Rhetorical devices to represent the ideas and morals of the book without directly referencing them so the reader can keep their interest by continuously thinking. This is what takes away from the movie, it sometimes says too much which doesn't make the viewer think to stay in tune so they pay less attention. Since that is the strategy of to portray the ideas of the movie, timshell is not said therefore it is not a part of theme of the movie. That not only takes away from the movies depth but the role and relationship with other characters for Lee.
The film itself is built with a strong plot by emotions the characters represent. Each individual character plays a role beyond their actions by these emotions that help the audience understand the point of view and deep thoughts of the characters without having to physically saying them. All the emotions mixed with the tones that are expressed by the characters help reach the depth of each idea in the situations that arise.
Although the movie describes the idea of the movie directly, the strong beliefs portrayed by the characters keep the audience interested while also giving emotion and life to the movie.

Directed by Elian Kazan, East of Eden has its strong points but the majority of the film is of poor quality.

    It is reasonable to say that this movie should be considered a classic for being based on of American literature's greatest works, but this classic fell short. In terms of entertainment it was decent, but if you were looking for a perfect transition from novel to movie you'd have to look elsewhere. For starters, the acting in this film was sub-par and for the entire movie there was a disconnection between actor and audience in the sense that it was difficult to understand what the actors wanted you to feel. The tone wasn't conveyed properly and therefore comprehension of the story was minimal. To go along with below average portrayal of the characters, the storyline missed important details of the novel that were needed for some of the major themes and ideas. Granted the book has too much to put into one movie, they still should've included more about Timshel, a key theme throughout the book.The only thing that made the movie watchable was the fight scene, but this is only because of how  immature the acting seemed with their unrecognizable muffled shouts.
    Although East of Eden is a classic in its own right it is a movie that falsely portrays  ideas given in the novel and has a moderate entertainment level due to the lack of execution on the actors behalf.

East of Eden Movie Review
	East of Eden, written by John Steinbeck and directed by Elia Kazan, provided a good general idea, but left out two of the most important factors of the book in the form of Lee and the Hebrew word, Timshel.
	East of Eden was written to show the ultimate conflict between good and evil. The movie did a wonderful job of keeping good and evil equal and opposite throughout the movie. Cal and Aron were the best examples of this. Early in the movie, Cal was portrayed as evil while Aron represented all that was good. Late in the movie, the role was switched as Aron became the bad child when he left his father, however Cal took on the role of good and was there for his father.
	A major gap in the movie was the absence of Lee, Adam?s servant. Lee had gotten Adam over his depression, as well as always tried to convince Cal that there was good in everyone. Lee was seen as the median in the book between Adam and his son, Cal. The tension between the two was evident, but without Lee, the resolution of Cal to be with his father was much less significant.
	As previously stated, this entire novel was based around the idea of good opposing evil. The main point in the novel was that each person had the ability to make their own decisions and choose right from wrong. Lee was the first to reveal this idea to the Trask family. The fact that the most important philosophy in the novel was left out completely defeats the entire purpose for making a movie without it. This was the ultimate factor as to why this movie was a big disappointment and completely destroyed the novel?s only purpose.
	Although this movie was relatively interesting, it turned away from the book too much to be enjoyable to anyone who has read the novel. Although you could follow the movie along pretty smoothly, without Lee and the main idea of Timshel, the movie lacked the clarity the book had and that was the ultimate downfall of the movie.

Elia Kazan's adaptation of John Steinbeck's novel was generally pretty well written in regards to the original text. However, the movie failed to capture the intense struggles of free will and good and evil that were omnipresent throughout Steinbeck's novel. Kazan's choice of starting the movie two-thirds of the way into the story completely cuts out important background information on Adam and Cathy. Kazan also cuts out the Samuel Hamilton and Lee, two major characters who provided great significance to the overall plot of the novel. One of the most critical points in the novel is when Adam, Lee, and Samuel discuss the story of Cain and Abel and their realization of man's ability to choose. The result of its exclusion from the movie leaves the audience with a broken perspective about the true motive of the novel and its overall themes.

    James Dean's performance of Cal similarly had its ups and downs. Where Cal in the book struggled between good and evil, James Dean represented wonderfully. However, Dean portrayed Cal as extremely depressed and mopey all the time, which overall limited his character and his ability to connect with the audience. Cal's relationship with Aron was not as strained as it was made in the movie, and the viewers couldn't have possibly been able to understand the true friendship that had existed between the brothers. 
    Overall, Kazan failed to truly captivate the audience with the same effect and strength as Steinbeck had done in his novel, even though Kazan made very obvious attempts to remain with the storyline. Through all these errors, the movie failed in living up to the standards set by Steinbeck's great work and his philosophies.

For those who are devout followers the author John Steinbeck and his famous work East of Eden, I warn you now! This movie is yet another example of the horrifying loss of intelligence between what's on paper and what shows up on the big screen. Less than half of Steinbeck's original story has survived the brutal chopping block called Hollywood. It is a true tragedy that a story once filled with noble themes such as Good versus Evil and a person's free will to choose between them has be reduced to a story of two brothers fighting over the love of their father and a girl. The beautiful parallels that Steinbeck wrote between Cyrus and Adam's fatherhood, Charles and Cal's roles as unloved, and the contrast between the Hamilton and the Trask families are gone.  In fact many of these characters never came to life at all. Samuel Hamilton and Lee, the two main fatherly figures of the story, were completely written out, despite the major emphasis on fatherly love portrayed in the movie. Even the characters that are included in the movie are lacking, especially Kate, who's true evil nature is never explained. The only redeeming point in this entire movie that I can see is Abra, the girl in love. Her switch between loving Aron to loving Cal is much more seamless in the movie than in the book. However, the way the boys interact with each other over her is poorly acted out, especially the fight scene. Over this entire movie didn't reach my expectations at all. I expected a retelling of the story of Cain and Abel with a twist. I did not expect a story of love conquers all. Save that for the fairytales.
This is an authentic James Dean film. It could have been directed by Elia Kazan, who did it wonderfully, but James Dean is the power of this overwhelming film.

The 1955 film adaptation of "East of Eden", directed by Elia Kazan, takes on the daunting task of retelling the rich, emotional storyline put down by John Steinbeck. 
Unfortunately so, watching the said movie after reading the book was severely disappointing. I couldn't get the full experiance in the film as i did in the book, but I will say that the acting for Abra was my favorite. The opening seemed too adrupt for there to be any detail, and i felt lost throughout the movie even having known the previous plot. Leaving out such a crucial character like Lee seemed like a major setback as well, and removed "Timshel" from ever happening at the ending, which was a major factor into the ending of the novel. The brief and few apperances of Cathy was dissapointing as well, but her actor did well in making up for such a short screen time. Also, the cinimatography was quite stunning, but I'm not too big of a fan on the "burn't cheese pizza" lettering they used for opening and closing credits. I'm sure Kazan tried his best to create a realistic interpretation of the book, and i know that you shouldn't ever compare a book to a movie adaptation. But I feel that East of Eden can be successfully shown with the right about of timing, plot progession, and character development.

A brilliant story about the complications of good, bad, hate and love. It shows not all bad people have bad intentions, and vice versa for the"pure-hearted", and overall, the power of love and hate steer these motivations. James Dean has a smash hit performance portraying Cal's arc from beginning to end, from misunderstanding to acceptance at the end.

James Dean makes his film debut in Elia Kazan's adaptation of John Steonbeck's novel. I've not read the book, but it seems this focuses on a much smaller version of the story, which is good, as film is a different medium from novels (something today's filmmakers could learn from...you don't need to adapt word for word). Essentially the film is a family drama about sibling rivalry and jealousy for a father's love. Dean is quite good in the lead and you can see why he was so instantly popular. Quite a good film.

The James Dean film that gets less airplay compared to Rebel Without a Cause and Giant, East of Eden is nonetheless another prime example of what good acting Dean successfully brought to the screen. I think this was the last one which is a shame.
Well, it's hard to watch without having so much sorrow. It's a beautiful movie.

Having seen the more famous "Rebel Without A Cause" I had always wondered if Dean was just a legend- a good actor with timeless good looks who made a great career move by dying young. In that film he is magnetic, but there's not really any depth there and he looks too old to really be just a teenager. Here however, (impressively given that it was his film debut!) he shows there was more to him than being able to play the good looking outsider who's 'complicated'. His performance utterly shows us the man had real acting chops, beyond looking young and old at the same time. To be such a master of your craft so young is truly impressive. Everyone else is very good as well, and the story and direction work well but really this is Dean's film. He just runs away with it and leaves everyone else in the dust.
"I'm Bad." This movie was really stupid.
James dean has a magnetic screen presence but Kazan has assembled a fine supporting cast in a humanist interpretation of Cain and Abel.

One of the only films I've ever seen that makes masterful use of the thematic trope of "daddy issues," "East of Eden" sears itself into your brain, leaving the imprint of a beautifully acted and stunningly shot classic.
Wow... Boggled by this one. Nothing like the epic book by Steinbeck. It was almost like this was simply an episode of the book. I was expecting a lot more from this one...
great backdrop and a messed up family unit to get you hating/loving as you go.
Great performance, Dean is perfect. Despite the movie being old, I still can connect with it. Very intense and a movie you have to watch.

It's been about ten years since I've last seen this film but it's as intense and emotional as I remember.  A great story, wonderfully acted and directed though my only issue is the ending and not knowing the fate of Cal's brother Aron.

In his first great film role, James Dean plays a rebellious son named Cal Trask who lives with his father and brother Aron in Salinas. Directed by Elia Kazan from the Steinbeck novel, the movie chronicles Cal's struggles in the shadow of his favored brother Aron. Despite good intentions at first, Cal is constantly rejected the praise that his brother garners. Thus embittered, he lashes out at his brother, falls for Aron's girl, and turns their father's world upside down. With his performance Dean brings alive the character who is himself an allegory for Cain. Julie Harris, Raymond Massey, and Jo Van Fleet all deliver good performances that play off Cal. Overall this is a classic adaption of a classic author.

Set around the first World War, two brothers compete for the love of their father. Elia Kazan brings the famous Steinbeck novel perfectly to the screen, in a powerful dramatic film filled with great compelling energy and gripping emotional tension. The photography is wonderful and conveys the feeling of the screenplay perfectly. This film is also known for being the debut of James Dean, whose excellent performance is the perfect embodiment of that teenage frustration, restlessness and general unhappiness as well as a forever rebellious youth which he would go on to become a symbol of.
Really good...first James Dean film I've seen, I think.

Though the film had some good attributes, it did not do justice to the book. James Dean did a nice job of depicting Cal and I thought the cinematography was well done.  The bar scene where you see the two brothers positioned one behind the other after the mob fight was especially great.  There was a comic book/cartoonish quality to that scene that I thought was really interesting.  The last scene was touching.  Beyond this, the movie was a really poor representation of the book. Abra's character was especially completely miscast.  While she is supposed to have a 'mature' personality, her maturity is not as one dimensional as it was represented. Her demeanour in the film was so over the top earnest and wholesome that I found her to be an incredibly irritating character that lacked depth.  She is a much more complex character in the book and this did not show through in the movie at all.  Cathy Ames (the mother) should have been much more devilish in character.  She never justifies why she is the way she is so blatantly in the book as she does in the film.  Cathy is a far more interesting character than simply a cut throat business woman as she is portrayed in the film.  Cal and Aaron's relationship was treated very superficially.  Their connection is characterized by both love and hate, yet the movie did not do a fair job of depicting this ambivalence. In contrast to the movie, the theme of jealousy in the book is a lot more subtle and underlying yet just as destructive.  The movie was unable to capture the seething quality of the emotion.  Cal never blatantly says he is jealous, he just is and its something he torturously struggles with.  Also, Cal and Abra never get together romantically until after Aaron goes to war.  The only borderline non-platonic encounter that he and Abra have prior to this time, is when Cal whispers something dirty in her ear when they are children.  One of the biggest problems with the movie is that they left out one of the central characters --Lee-- the Chinese care taker and friend of the family.  Lee is such a pivotal character in the book that I was shocked that he was included in the film.  Overall, I could not get myself to like the movie too much.  Perhaps my opinion of the film would have been different had I not read the book.
James Dean is great as Cal, and the choice to skip the first 60% of the novel's storyline proves surprisingly effective.

I just had read the book a few weeks ago so I wanted to see the movie.  As usual, the book was way better.  If I didn't read the book I think I would have been sort of lost at the story.  There was to much details left out I think.  I had never even really watched an old movie like this.  Overall, it was an ok movie. I've seen much worse.  Besides that James Dean is cute, I think that Brad Pitt sort of resembles him a bit.

extreamly dissapointing! 2 stars simply because I love James Dean

It's not very good if you read the book before hand. The book is about 600 pages, and it's an amazing book. Imagine some ridiculous script writer chopping off the first 400 pages and making a movie only about the last 200. It's annoying. There is so much to this story, so many unanswered questions. The book was better than Gone With The Wind's story in my opinion, and if it had been made 3-4 hours long, I bet we'd have a really good movie. It would've been on par with Gone With The Wind. I give this a 3 stars for it's effort and James Dean's performance. And overall, I just didn't enjoy the movie so much.

A timeless and profoundly touching retelling of the Biblical story of Cain and Abel using the early 20th century California as backdrop. While the visuals and music are wonderful, it is James Dean's performance the most spectacular here, especially in the poignant final scene.

Better known as the first role for James Dean, East of Eden is laregely forgotten about for anything else. The acting is very good and it's directed by one of the greats, Elia Kazan, but for some reason I just couldn't get into this. It seems overlong just a bit even though it's just under 2 hours. This film might take another viewing or two to get into, but I don't even know about that. Dean, though, shows glimpses of what he could've been had he lived longer. The guy was a wonderful actor.

One of my top favourites. A truly great film from Elia Kazan, which I believe had James Dean's best performance (although I'm yet to see ''Giant''). He could play a rebel/misunderstood teenager like no other. Based on the self-titled novel by the great Nobel Prize winner John Steinbeck (which is also loosely based on the Cain/Abel biblical storyline). Poignant, timeless stuff. Highly recommended.

A classic  film adaption to John Steinbeck's novel, James Dean portrays Cal Trask (also an anagram to Stark, the name of James Dean's character in Rebel without a Cause),  a lonely outcast who re-enters into his mother's life while still trying to gain his father's approval and love (as he did in real life with his father). James Dean took his emotional problems and put them on screen that gave him a performance that earned him an oscar nomination.

The biggest pile of crap ever put on celluloid.  It's an absolute joke and should be stripped of the title of the book it borrows from.  At best it's an adaption (a very poor one at that) of the final 40 pages of a nearly 600 page book.  The only reason this film has any notoriety is because it stars James Dean (who is about 5-years older than the character in the book he's supposed to portray).  NEVER see this movie.  Read the book.
Only problem with James Dean is that he, not surprisingly, steals the show from others who do well also.

At least from a career standpoint, I don't know if I feel more sorry for James Dean or, well, anyone else in this film who isn't James Dean. Forget east of Eden, just about everyone else's careers went south after this film. Okay, maybe the supporting cast didn't fall that fast, though they didn't really take off all that much after this film film, and all the while, James Dean didn't do but three roles that weren't uncredited bit parts before he died, and people are still talking about him, or at least about how he always looked so tired all the time. Well, to be fair, he did do some pretty good films, and he was really good in them, with this film being no exception, though what else would you expect from the director of "A Streetcar Named Desire" and... "The Last Tycoon"? Okay, I can think of some people who would say that we can just forget about that and just leave with our fond memories of Elia Kazan, of which, there are plenty, if you can remember them in the first place. A good bit of Kazan's work hasn't really stuck in everyone's memory banks all that deeply, yet the people who do remember his work can tell you that this film was certainly something to behold, being a classic masterpiece. To those people, I say shut up you annoying nostalgiacs, because while this film is good, it's not that good, being an Eden held back by a few corrupting snakes.

The film hits its slower spots, though rarely, if ever to a terribly dull degree, and what slow spots the film does hit are few and far between. However, were slowness more prevalent, it would most likely still be among the least of this film's worries, because the biggest blow to this film is that it is structurally all over the place. Now, the story isn't a total mess, with most everything scattered everwhere in the most unkept and uneven of fashions, yet the film is still quite uncomfortable in a lot of key places in its progression. Certain turns in storyline or focus are jarring and sudden, lacking enough time for you to fully lock into the situation, thus leaving the film a tad disengaging here and there, while other certain sudden shifts - particularly when it comes to characters - render the film a tad hard to follow. Still, it all comes down to long lines of non-oomph, with the film not really falling all that limp, though not really taking off that far when it does finally pick up. For all extents and purposes, this should be just another average film that rests among the workmanlike pile of films that have earned notoriety, mainly because of the stars who head. However, this film is better than that, perhaps falling a bit too limp at points, though not to where it completely falls out of being genuinely good, being made so by quite a few aspects that are mostly subtle, yet make quite a difference.

Okay, now, maybe Ted D. McCord's cinematography doesn't necessarily make quite a difference, as it is only occasionally outstanding, yet when it does stand out, it's pretty impressive. Early on in the film, a scene in which James Dean's Cal Trask character is made to read excerpt from the Bible is riddled with very cleverly staged and lit camera shots that really capture the hint of bleakness in the air that reflects our characters and really sets up the themes of the film, in which you can find quite a few other fancy and effective shots of this nature. Still, again, these fine shots are too sporadic to stick a landing as a key strength to telling this story, so in order for this film to really be good, it's just got to be a good story. Well, sure enough, while the story structure is very messy, the overall product presented is generally compelling, with intriguing themes and concepts that help keep it afloat, yet not without the help of some upstanding performances. Sure, Julie Harris is pretty bad, when not simply mediocre, yet most everyone else is engagingly charismatic, though there are some standouts, such as Jo Van Fleet, whose surprisingly fairly subtle and thoughtful portrayal of an untrusting and very business-oriented woman facing the risk of changing tremendously when considerably grand events and discoveries begin to fall into her life makes her among your more compelling aspects to the film. As for James Dean, with all of my joking around about how he's become such a big icon, even with his paper-slim filmography, he got those Oscar nominations and all of this notoriety for a reason, as he was the original great actor to lose young, something made clear very early on in the film as he very charismatically, yet ever so believably manages to nail the ticks and eccentricities of such a disturbed and clearly unhealthy person like the Cal Trask character in a fashion that definately leaves you aware that our lead is not all there, yet still has enough competence in him to hold layers. Well, sure enough, while the writing leaves those layers to jar in on occasion, Dean never lets up on making the complexities within his character very organic, presenting a person who is well-intentioned and reasonably competent, even with his problems, looking for self-value and respect as a good man, thus making for a very restrained, yet very engrossing lead performance that stands as further testament to just what we miss about the late, great Mr. Dean.

Overall, outside of a few slow spots, the real blow to the film is its structural messiness, from jarring story shifts to sudden character changes, that leave the film a bit hard to follow and often rather disengaging, while long periods of limited oomph leave the film to run the risk of descending to simply average, yet it manages to its own, secured by occasions of clever cinematography and consistency in story compellingness, really brought to life by generally strong performances, the strongest of which being delivered by the late, great James Dean, whose layered, subtle and enthralling lead performance helps in ultimately making "East of Eden" a mostly intriguing study on morality and value.

3/5 - Good
My favourite of James Dean's short career, classic.

Dean's performance is great - but occasionally unfocused. I applaud Kazan's directing and choice of camera work - but all in all many aspects of this film feel forced and unbelievable, especially in comparison to  some of Kazan's other films.

Much like John Steinbeck's novel of the same name, East of Eden has always seemed like a kind of reflection of my values and beliefs as a person. Elia Kazan's film is devastatingly powerful and hauntingly beautiful.
Dean at his anst-y best.

The film version of Eden is actually only about a third of the whole novel, choosing to focus mainly on the Cain and Abel-like story of Dean's Cal Trask and his tumultuous relationship with his father Adam. As in the bible story, most of Adam's love is reserved for Cal's brother Aron, while Cal, desperate for his fathers attention and approval, somehow only seems to be able to curry his disappointment. 
Leonardo DiCaprio has said that before filming a movie, he watches (or used to anyway) East of Eden again and again, studying Dean's performance. I personally feel this is the lesser of Dean's three starring roles, which isn't to say it's a bad one. Dean is an incredibly naturalistic actor, known for his improvisational style and realistic delivering of dialogue. He reminds me very much of young Marlon Brando. It's perhaps no big surprise that Brando's game changing performance in 1954's On the Waterfront seems to inform the performances that Dean gave a year later. 
The movie itself is well told and actually quite a bit darker than you would think for 1955. It's full of the kind of teen angst and anti-authoritarian overtones that would fill Dean's next, most iconic film, Rebel Without A Cause.
The acting is great, although Kazan's crazy camera angles are a little too precocious.
Great direction by Elia Kazan and a moving performance by James Dean.

surprisingly heavy and depressing, "east of eden" is fantastic in almost every way. it's a true 50's classic, with pretty experimental cinematography for it's time. yes, the plot of a rebellious young adult acting out because he's never felt his father's love and approval. but this movie is written incredibly well, particularly the dialogue. "east of eden" is a must see for anyone who calls themselves a cinefile.

Sad and powerful story, based on the book by John Steinbeck of the name, about a young man named Cal (James Dean) who is in search of himself and quite distraught for that matter. He is still wounded by the fact his mother (Jo Van Fleet) left (although initially there was belief she died) his unbelievably religious father (Raymond Massey) when he was young. Cal is also struggling to gain affection from his father, since he has to compete against his brother (Richard Davalos). To achieve some possible affection by his father, Cal decides to borrow money from his recently discovered mother in order to grow beans to offset losses from a failed business venture that his father had through a refrigeration failure of vegetables on a train. If there are parts of the novel left out, the remainder used for the movie is compelling enough to get through. Dean, Van Fleet, and Julie Harris, who plays the role of his brother's fiancée, are fine in their performances. It is also the last film I needed to see with Dean, in which this is his breakthrough role. It was also released the same year as another wonderful film with Dean, "Rebel Without a Cause," which I thought was a bit better than "East of Eden." However, this film is still very well done.
Still think Dean is/ was overrated, but this film is better than "Rebel Without A Cause". Perhaps Steinbeck has something to do with that.
James Dean, when all is said and done, is not the best actor and the reason this movie is considered a classic is because of his death and the fantasitc directing by Elia Kazan.

James Dean is so good here. This is the best performance of his three movies.

Grade: A-

and  yet  again  James  Dean  delivers  a  masterpiece  performance  which  you  cannot  help  but to be  drawn  his  performance  Overall  i thought  the film  was  very  well done  and  the  story   is  something  that  should be  paid  close attention  to  given  the nature  and  content  of  the  film

Wow. That movie is simply ageless. Great and legendary performance by James Dean.

Based on a novel by John Steinbeck, and directed by Elia Kazan, this is the first film in the James Dean Trilogy.

Set in Salinas, California in 1917, this is the story of Cal (Dean) a young wayward man who competes with his brother Aron (Dick Davalos) for the affections of their hardened father Adam (Raymond Massey). It's basically a Cain and Abel type of story, and agriculture plays an important role even. It's not a strict adaptation of that story, but it is the best reference point to use to describe things.

Things are rather dramatic, though they dip into melodrama at times. And, in typical Kazan fashion, there's a lot of subtext, mostly since the imminent entrance of the U.S. into World War i and anti-German sentiment plays a fairly sizable role throughout.

It took me a bit to get interested and involved, but once I tapped into this film's groove, I enjoyed it quite a bit. Like the other two film's Dean did I do think it's overrated to a degree, but it's still pretty solid even then. Of the three, this one's #2 for me behind Rebel Without a Cause.

It's good, but personally I didn't think it was outstanding or anything. The acting is terrific though, and there's some great camerawork, but it just didn't completely seem like my thing. If it were, I'd probably have a somewhat higher opinion of it. Still though, it's getting a really solid recommendation from me.

Say hello to your mother

In a small California valley town just before World War I a single father raising two boys experiences issues with an investment in frozen vegetables.  The farmer has one straight and narrow boy that does well in school and lives a relatively normal life.  He also has an eccentric boy who wants to help his dad recover his lost fortune.  The eccentric boy looks up his mother, who he was told is dead, and hopes to rekindle enough of a relationship to garner some money to invest in a venture to repay his father's losses.

"How did you know it was true?"
"Because she ain't no good and I ain't no good."

Elia Kazan, director of A Streetcar Named Desire, On the Waterfront, Baby Doll, Splendor in the Grass, The Last Tycoon, and A Tree Grows in Brooklyn, delivers East of Eden.  The storyline for this picture is mesmerizing and extremely intense.  It reminded me of a cross between What's Eating Gilbert Grape and The Long Hot Summer.  The acting was mesmerizing and the cast includes James Dean, Julie Harris, Lois Smith, and Jo Van Fleet.

"Is there anything nice about her at all?"

This is my first ever James Dean movie and I found it equal in terms of quality to A Streetcar Named Desire and On the Waterfront.  This is an epic picture with great acting and fascinating characters.  This is a must see for students of film and storytelling and another great picture by the wonderful Elia Kazan.

"She wasn't like other people."

Grade: A+

I don't know the original book that served as the basis, but I would like to say that this film was one of those that made James Dean a legend, in the role of a young man who struggles to find his place in a puritanical society and,I don't know the original book that served as the basis, but I would like to say that this film was one of those that made James Dean a legend, in the role of a young man who struggles to find his place in a puritanical society and, especially, in the heart from his strict father and estranged mother. A classic that does not show the years.
Great movie that I enjoyed, a matter of pop culture because of Steinbeck and Dean. Acting is on point, story satisfiable, although left ambiguous.

It's not only James Dean but everybody's amazing performance that make East Of Eden incredible, it's a simple story but they make it more darker and it just way better than i expected to be, East Of Eden is a truly amazing film.

rt_summary: In this film based on John Steinbeck's epic novel, Cal Trask (James Dean), the son of a California farmer (Raymond Massey), feels that his father cares only about his brother, Aron (Richard Davalos). When Cal embarks on a business venture to gain the favor of his dad, he finds himself dealing with his estranged mother (Jo Van Fleet), now the owner of a brothel, and tensions in the family rise even further when he begins to fall for Aron's girlfriend, Abra (Julie Harris).
meta_summary: A wilful young man contends against his brother for the attention of their religious father while reconnecting with his estranged mother and falling for his brother's girlfriend.
